prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3 Polarization Observations of 6 Blazars
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
We will observe 6 blazars in band 3 in full polarization mode to measure degree and position angle of linear polarization.
Note that due to a limitation in the observing tool requiring sources with > 10 degrees separation to appear as separate science goals, we have created 6 separate science goals for each band. However, our blazars are strong, point-like sources to ALMA and should not require separate phase calibrators and can therefore be observed together in a single session. This will greatly reduce the calibration overhead (a minimum of 3 hours for D-terms is enforced by the OT for each science goal).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe 6 blazars to determine the wavelength dependence of their linear polarization and Faraday rotation measure at mm/sum-mm wavelengths. All 6 blazars are from the BU group's current VLBA monitoring program and have appropriate declinations, flux densities > 1 Jy at 1mm, linear polarization > 10% at 1 mm (based on previous observations by Nartallo et al. 1998 & Jorstad et al. 2007), and VLBI images in polarized intensity at 7 and 3 mm (observations by the BU group approved for 2014). We request all three bands (3, 6, and 7) that are available for full polarization observations in Cycle 2. All of our requested sources are point sources to ALMA, so any array configuration is suitable for these observations. We will combine the data from the two upper and two lower IF frequencies to give us two spectral points in each continuum band. Our desired sensitivity is 0.2 mJy for each of these pairs of IFs, so we have chosen an RMS of 0.14 mJy with full continuum bandwidth in the OT. This level of sensitivity will allow our linear polarization observations to be calibration-limited at 0.1% of the expected source strength of > 1.0 Jy for each target.
Note that due to a limitation in the observing tool requiring sources with > 10 degrees separation to appear as separate science goals, we have created 6 separate science goals for each band. However, our blazars are strong, point-like sources to ALMA and should not require separate phase calibrators and can therefore be observed together in a single session. This will greatly reduce the calibration overhead (a minimum of 3 hours for D-terms is enforced by the OT for each science goal).
According to the OT Time Estimator, observations of all 6 sources, including calibrations (except D-term calibration), require 32 min in band 3, 34 min in band 6, and 54 min in band 7. Since band switching is not allowed for science targets in Cycle 2, observations at each band are implemented in the OT as a separate science goal. At each of these bands, D-term calibration extends the roughly 0.5-1 hr of target observing time to three hr in order to obtain sufficient parallactic angle coverage. Hence, the total time requested is 9 hr. However, according to ALMA_Cycle-2_Technical_Handbook_v1.pdf (10.2.8 Polarization Calibration), the entire polarization calibration requires ~5 calibrator observations evenly spaced during at least a 3 hr scheduling block (SB). Since switching between bands is allowed for calibrator observations, we propose the following method of observations: 1) schedule all three bands (i.e. all three science goals) back-to-back over a roughly three hour period; 2) within these 3 hr, for example, devote the first 32 min to target observations in band 3, then 34 min in band 6, and then 54 min in band 7; 3) within these 3 hr monitor a D-term calibrator at least 5 times, each time in all three bands with frequency switching between bands 3, 6, and 7. This would shorten the required total observation time from 9 hours (for all three bands together) to 3 hours and reduce the chance of source variability (as short as 0.25 days at 1 mm) during the observations.

According to the OT Time Estimator, observations of all 6 sources, including calibrations (except D-term calibration), require 32 min in band 3, 34 min in band 6, and 54 min in band 7. Since band switching is not allowed for science targets in Cycle 2, observations at each band are implemented in the OT as a separate science goal. At each of these bands, D-term calibration extends the roughly 0.5-1 hr of target observing time to three hr in order to obtain sufficient parallactic angle coverage. Hence, the total time requested is 9 hr. However, according to ALMA_Cycle-2_Technical_Handbook_v1.pdf (10.2.8 Polarization Calibration), the entire polarization calibration requires ~5 calibrator observations evenly spaced during at least a 3 hr scheduling block (SB). Since switching between bands is allowed for calibrator observations, we propose the following method of observations: 1) schedule all three bands (i.e. all three science goals) back-to-back over a roughly three hour period; 2) within these 3 hr, for example, devote the first 32 min to target observations in band 3, then 34 min in band 6, and then 54 min in band 7; 3) within these 3 hr monitor a D-term calibrator at least 5 times, each time in all three bands with frequency switching between bands 3, 6, and 7. This would shorten the required total observation time from 9 hours (for all three bands together) to 3 hours and reduce the chance of source variability (as short as 0.25 days at 1 mm) during the observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe 6 blazars in full polarization in bands 3, 6, and 7. We will use the data to determine the linear polarization and Faraday rotation (FR) at mm/submm wavelengths which will be the first measurements of this kind ever performed. The proposed observations will probe the structure and matter content of the innermost jets of these blazars. In particular, the inferred magnetic field order and Faraday rotation at mm/submm wavelengths in comparison with longer wavelengths will decide among models for the mm-wave "core" of the jet. These observations will also allow initial tests of the circular polarization capabilities of ALMA with a future goal of proposing high accuracy circular polarization observations of blazars to test the dominance of protons over positrons in the jet.
We note that the observing tool (OT) has calculated a total observing time for this request of 54 hours due to the separate science goals required for targets at > 10 degree separations. Our strong, point-like blazars will serve as their own phase calibrators; thus we estimate our proposed observations can be completed in as little as 3 hours in total.
